awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Relating Topographic Complexity and Circulation Patterns on Coral Reefs from Colony-Scale to Reef-Scale
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important coastal marine systems either grow on or form complex topography that varies continuously over a wide range of spatial scales. For example, on coral reefs, topography varies from branch (centimeter) to patch (10-100 meters) to reef (several kilometers) scales. In the coastal ocean, water motion is forced past topography at a wide range of time scales by surface waves, tides and slowly varying currents. Understanding how these flows interact with complex multi-scale topography is critical for predicting circulation patterns in shallow coastal systems like reefs. At present, the physics of these interactions is not included explicitly in observational efforts or modeling studies and one of the biggest challenges for predictive modeling of circulation in coastal systems like reefs is a lack of methods for a priori estimation of drag and mixing parameters from topography spatial statistics. This project will provide a theoretical and conceptual framework for flow over complex topography in the coastal ocean that includes the physics of interactions of currents and waves with multi-scale topography. New parameterizations for flow over complex topography will be developed for use in ocean circulation models to improve their predictive ability in important coastal systems like coral reefs. Improved predictions of circulation over reefs should then lead to better estimates of cross-reef  exchange and transport of nutrients and contaminants, as well as a better description of larval retention, dispersion and connectivity.  The field study will be conducted at the NSF-supported Moorea Coral Reef Long Term Ecological Research (MCR-LTER) site which brings together many leaders in coral reef science. Through planned interactions with MCR-LTER and French/Tahitian researchers the results will directly reach a multi-disciplinary international audience. A PhD student will be trained in physical oceanographic field work, modeling, and theory, and gain interdisciplinary and international experience by interacting with the MCR-LTER. At least nine undergraduate students will conduct independent studies and write honors theses related to the project.

In this project, a theoretical and conceptual framework will be developed for the interaction of currents and waves with multi-scale topography. A set of novel field measurements and simulations will examine how flow with different time scales interacts with topography characterized by different obstacle size, spacing, and patchiness. Topography spatial statistics will be computed from high-resolution satellite bathymetry and 3D scanning sonar measurements. Spatial variability in currents on the reef at scales from 0.2-500 meters will be quantified using a nested sampling array. Field measurements over constructed geometries will investigate how natural flow that varies at a range of time scales interacts with bottom topography with different length scales. Numerical modeling of steady and unsteady flow over idealized reef geometries and real reef segments will examine dynamics of flow-topography interactions across the range of currents, waves, and topography length scales at the field site.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

In coastal systems like coral reefs the movement of water affects many biological, chemical, and physical processes. Topography on reefs varies across a wide range of spatial scales from coral branches, colonies, and patches, to the entire reef. The frictional forces exerted on moving water by reef topography resist currents and remove energy from waves. Quantifying friction exerted by the complex bottom is therefore critical for predicting currents and waves on reefs; however, it is challenging due to the large range of topography length-scales. Traditional methods for representing friction on flow rely on specifying a single roughness length scale that represents the bottom topography; however, it is unclear how appropriate this is for multi-scale topography. There is a need to represent the frictional force exerted by the bottom on waves and current using statistical properties of the topography. The project addressed this issue by combining measurements and analyses of real reef topography and computer simulations of flow over idealized geometries where flow parameters were varied systematically. 

In our computer simulations of combined waves and current over topography, we examined how the relative sizes of length-scales associated with the flow and length-scales associated with the topography affected the frictional forces on the flow. The characteristics of flow over the topography depended strongly on two dimensionless numbers: the Keulegan-Carpenter number (KC) representing the ratio of the distance water moves in a wave cycle to the size of topographic features, and Uw/Uc the ratio of the oscillatory water velocity due to waves to the steady water velocity due to current. The KC dependence was weak when Uw/Uc was small (current dominated) and strong when Uw/Uc was large (wave dominated). This was reflected in the friction factor fw that relates the drag on the flow to the average flow speed. Drag on the current increased with increasing waves (Uw/Uc). Drag on waves increased with current strength (Uc/Uw) for small KC but varied little with current for large KC. These patterns were well explained by a quadratic dependence of drag on instantaneous velocity in the obstacle layer together with observed variations in flow separation strength. This part of the study provides new insights into interactions of waves and currents with topography, with important consequences for parameterizing bottom friction on reefs.

We also collected high resolution topography measurements on a coral reef and analyzed them to investigate the statistical properties of the topography and test approaches for computing geometric parameters that are important for determining drag on the flow. We showed that the reef topography was not only multi-scale but also multi-fractal meaning that the way topography varied with spatial scale varied with position. We estimated the frontal area of topography seen by the flow per unit ground area by (1) representing the reef as an obstacle array, and (2) deriving new expressions to calculate it directly from topography elevation values. The two approaches did not agree because small-scale variations contributed substantially to total frontal area. We also made high-resolution hydrodynamic measurements across 2D slices using a novel 3-axis sliding frame deployed on the same coral reef patches. The results showed persistent spatial patterns in currents, wave orbital velocities and turbulence that co-varied with the topography. These results illustrate that parameterizations of bottom friction on reefs should consider the complete range of topographic length scales rather than representing a reef by an idealized obstacle array or a single length scale.

 

Broader Impacts

This project has improved the understanding of water flow on coral reefs, which will lead to better prediction of flow across reefs. Corals reefs are one of the most diverse marine ecosystems and also support important fishing and tourism industries. Flow affects many aspects of coral reef health. Predictive models of flow across reefs are needed to assess impacts of human activities such as land use effects on sediment and nutrient delivery, and effects of warming and acidification associated with elevated carbon emission. More accurate predictive models of flow across coral reefs informed by this project will enable better predictions of human impacts, thereby contributing to more informed management decisions.

By conducting our research at the NSF Coral Reef Long Term Ecological Research site in Moorea (MCR-LTER) and interacting with MCR-LTER researchers our work informed other coral reef research and reached a multi-disciplinary international audience. Project results appeared in 12 papers in top tier scientific journals and 11 conference presentations. We organized a successful session on interactions between topography and flow for the 2016 AGU Ocean Sciences Meeting. The project formed the basis for one postdoctoral project and a PhD dissertation. Through their involvement in the project, three PhD students were trained in physical oceanographic field work, modeling, and theory. Ten undergraduates used data and models from this project for REUs, independent studies, and honors theses.
